sources.data_found: TOP500 site page for New York University listing Torch (2025) and Greene (2020) systems and their core counts; Torch entry indicates NVIDIA H200 SXM5 141GB; Greene entry is CPU-only.
TOP500 system page for Torch: HPE Cray XD670, Xeon Platinum 8592+ 64C, NVIDIA H200 SXM5 141GB; Total CPU cores = 33,152; Installation year = 2025.
Torch described as equipped with 'more than 500 NVIDIA H200 GPUs'.
TOP500 system page for Greene-H100: Lenovo ThinkSystem SD665-N V3, AMD EPYC 9454 48C; Total CPU cores = 9,360; Installation year = 2024; indicates NVIDIA H100 80GB.
Lenovo SD665-N V3 datasheet: node supports NVIDIA HGX H100 or H200 4-GPU acceleration (4 GPUs per node).
Greene cluster (legacy description): 73 RTX8000 GPU nodes; 20 V100 GPU nodes; 9 A100 GPU nodes; total GPU cards reported: 292 RTX8000 (48GB) and 76 V100 (32GB).

student_data.notes: Searched for NYU Computer Science (CS) student enrollment counts specifically for Fall 2024 / AY 2024-2025 across: (1) NYU CS department pages (cs.nyu.edu), (2) NYU Common Data Set 2024-2025, (3) NYU registrar/institutional research enrollment statistics, and (4) NYU Tandon dashboards. I found an official NYU Tandon 'Fast Facts' page that clearly reports Fall 2024 total enrollment (7,602 total; 2,852 undergraduate; 4,750 graduate), but it does NOT break enrollment down by Computer Science major/program (so it cannot be used to populate CS-only counts). ([engineering.nyu.edu](https://engineering.nyu.edu/about/fast-facts?utm_source=openai)) I also found an NYU CS PhD overview page mentioning 'Starting Fall 2026' a single CS PhD program comprising 'over 250 full-time Ph.D. students', but it does not provide Fall 2024 / AY 2024-2025 CS PhD enrollment and is explicitly future-dated (2026), so it was rejected per your date rules. ([cs.nyu.edu](https://cs.nyu.edu/home/phd/))

gpu_resources.notes:
Clusters identified and GPU totals computed as follows:

1) Torch (NYU, TOP500 June 2025 entry; NVIDIA H200 SXM5)
- Press coverage states 'more than 500' H200 GPUs.
- Estimate used to satisfy nodes×GPUs_per_node requirement: 64 GPU nodes × 8 H200/node = 512 H200.
- Rationale: HPE Cray XD670 platforms are commonly deployed as 8-GPU HGX nodes; 512 matches 'more than 500'. (TOP500 does not list accelerator count.)

2) Greene-H100 (NYU, TOP500 2024 entry; NVIDIA H100 80GB)
- TOP500 lists 9,360 CPU cores; AMD EPYC 9454 is a 48-core CPU.
- Assumed dual-socket nodes: 2×48 = 96 CPU cores per node; nodes ≈ 9,360 / 96 = 97.5, rounded to 98 nodes (possible minor core disablement / reporting mismatch).
- Lenovo SD665-N V3 datasheet indicates 4 GPUs per node.
- H100 total estimate: 98 nodes × 4 H100/node = 392 H100.
- H100 counted as SXM (HGX) based on SD665-N V3 being an HGX-based 4-GPU platform.

3) Greene (legacy GPU pool; RTX8000 + V100 + A100)
- From Greene documentation snapshot: total GPU cards explicitly listed: 292 RTX8000 (48GB) and 76 V100 (32GB).
- RTX8000: treated as 73 nodes × 4 RTX8000/node = 292 (consistent with the reported 292 RTX8000).
- V100: treated as 19 nodes × 4 V100/node = 76 (matches the reported 76 V100; the same page also mentions 20 V100 nodes, which is inconsistent).
- A100: page mentions 9 A100 GPU nodes but does not report A100 GPU-card count or VRAM size.
  * Estimate used: 9 nodes × 4 A100/node = 36 A100.
  * A100 classified as 40GB (not 80GB) as an age-based/typical-config estimate because VRAM and form factor are not stated.

4) Hudson (incorporated into Greene; AMD MI50)
- 20 nodes × 8 MI50/node = 160 MI50 (32GB) recorded under other_high_vram_gpus (not one of the requested explicit NVIDIA categories).

No evidence found (in accessible sources used here) for NYU-owned A6000/L40S/P100/B100/B200/GH200/H100 PCIe counts; these are set to 0.

analysis_notes: Data collected via multi-query approach: separate student and GPU searches.
